Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Sources of Power and the Development of Sociopolitical Complexity in Malagana, Southwestern Colombia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the supervision of Dr. Robert D. Drennan, Hernando Giraldo will carry out a program of intensive surface collection and test excavations at the Malagana site in the Cauca River valley of southwestern Colombia. The earliest written documentation of Cauca valley societies, dating to the sixteenth century, describes wealthy and powerful chiefs leading small regional polities engaged in intensive conflict with each other. These historical sources have inspired much generalization about the role of conflict and warfare in early complex societies. There is, however, very little direct archaeological documentation of the developmental trajectories of Cauca valley societies or the bases of chiefly power in them. Thus one knows little about the social forces that produced the situation described in the accounts of early Spanish Conquistadores. Tombs excavated at the Malagana site have often contained extremely elaborate offerings of gold, ceramics, and other materials, and these are often taken as evidence of considerable wealth accumulation by the community's elites. In an unusually conspicuous suggestion of conflict, the site is surrounded by a ditch and embankment which may have served defensive purposes.

This research is important because it will contribute to understanding of the formation and maintenance of social inequalities and the nature of social power. The level of social complexity exhibited at Malagana is duplicated in many regions of the developing world today and through examination of an archaeological case where such processes can be followed across centuries significant insights can be gained.

Mr. Giraldo will systematically collect artifacts available on the surface of the densely occupied residential zone associated with the Malagana cemetery and ditch feature. Analysis of these artifacts will enable him to assess differences in the nature and costliness of possessions in different households and in the nature and intensity of both ritual and productive activities carried out in different places. His mapping of the residential zone will delineate its relationship to the possible defensive wall and help to determine whether that is in fact its function. Such information will make possible an assessment of the importance of several potential sources of social power that have been suggested for Cauca valley societies, including wealth accumulation based on agricultural surpluses, control over specialized craft production, participation in long-distance networks of exchange of prestige goods, leadership in warfare, and manipulation of belief systems. The Malagana site provides an extraordinary opportunity to increase understanding of the ways in which early leaders gained and used social and political power, and of how these strategies were modified through time.

The research will also have broader impacts. It will strengthen existing collaborative ties between U.S. researchers and those in several Colombian institutions. Its findings will be disseminated in national and international conferences and peer-review journal articles; the raw data will be available to scholars and the public online in the University of Pittsburgh's Comparative Archaeology Database. The field work will provide training to U.S. and Colombian students in archaeological field methods and in processing and analyzing cultural materials in the laboratory. The project will contribute to the local community's ongoing efforts to create an archaeological museum, combat the illicit excavation of archaeological sites, and enhance public understanding of the cultural and scientific value of archaeological remains.

Religion and ritual played an important role in the emergence of the earliest complex societies in many regions. It has often been suggested that political power based on religious belief, however, is limited, and that leaders who aspire to larger-scale political integration must find ways to enhance their power by extending control over important sectors of the economy. Archaeological research in Central America and northern South America has confirmed that religion was the principal mechanism for creating social inequalities in a number of regions. Some have taken this to be a general pattern for this part of the world.

Malagana, in the flat valley of the Cauca River of southern Colombia, however, stood out as a possible exception to such a pattern. Malagana is known for a large cemetery of tombs richly endowed with elaborate ceramics, gold, obsidian, emerald, greenstone and other luxury materials. These tombs date to between 400 BC and 800 AD, and other contemporaneous burials were entirely without grave goods. This evidence has suggested substantial differences in economic standing. Malagana also had earthworks for defensive purposes, an unusually conspicuous indication of conflict and warfare. There was no indication of religious monuments or spaces for ritual activities.

Under the supervision of Dr. Robert Drennan, Hernando Giraldo carried out a 32-ha systematic surface survey at Malagana. Using the artifacts recovered in association with different household areas across the village, the research evaluated: a. the distribution of wealth across households and their spatial association with lavish graves; b. the distribution of the production of both luxury and utilitarian goods and the association of such production with high-ranking households; c. the distribution of ritual activities; d. the localization of feasts and their spatial relationship with high-ranking houses; and e. evidence of conflict and warfare.

The artifact assemblages recovered indicate that, during the Early El Bolo period (400 BC-800AD, Malagana villagers enjoyed high standards of living. On average, wealth was more strongly in evidence in the southern sector of the settlement, near the richly furnished tombs. Also in the southern sector, production of luxury goods made of greenstone and slate, was highly concentrated and associated with one of the wealthiest households of the community. Gold artifacts were not exclusively produced in association with the wealthiest households, but their scarcity and restricted zone of production indicate that producers were attached to the elite consumers of such goods. In contrast, the production of utilitarian goods was widely dispersed, suggesting widespread production by households satisfying their own needs.

The non-elite population carried out household rituals not shared by the elite, but artifacts used in elite funerary practices did occur in a small way in non-elite contexts as well, suggesting that it was acceptable for commoners to emulate elite funerary ritual. Feasting was especially intense during the Early El Bolo period but not exclusive to elite contexts, possibly representing competition between different groups (or resistance to elites) rather than a mechanism by which leaders acquired or reinforced their power. Finally, warfare seems to have played an indirect but relevant role in the formation of social inequalities. There is no clear evidence that leaders were warriors or that they used warrior ideology for maintaining their positions, but the construction of defensive earthworks created a material, spatial division in the population, emphasizing the divide between the wealthier population who lived within the innermost walls and those outside, who were not so well off.
